content.description:
Starts left of some black flakes and climbs more or less straight up the face utilizing edges, slopers, crystal pinches and whatever else you can grab. The crux comes about two-thirds of the way up but the climbing is continuous throughout.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: The center of the south (roadside) face of the boulder.

content.description:
Climbs a just-off vertical face on sharp crimps and rounded slopers with the crux down low and gradually larger holds the higher you get. Just tall enough to keep your attention the whole way and best done when it's cooler or risk wrecking your tips.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: The left side of the south (roadside) face of the boulder.

content.description:
Start on some black flakes and work up the arete which transitions to grainy smears and edges higher.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: The right arete on the south (roadside) face of the boulder.

content.description:
This fun line climbs a slightly overhung face from lower right to upper left via incut edges, sidepulls, slopers and some cool moves.

The picnic table below the problem has been located away from the base and no longer presents a hazard.

* This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: West face of the boulder near a picnic table.

content.description:
Climb up the easy trough just right of

Picnic

and transition up and right onto the grainy low-angled slab complete with mystery holes. This is the easiest way up and down the boulder and also the standard descent route.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Just right of

Picnic

on the southeast edge of the boulder.
